data.title: Elton John -
data.meta_description: Elton John (born March 25, 1947) is an English vocalist, pianist, songwriter, and philanthropist with a career stretching back to the mid-1960s. He achieved global stardom with his self-titled second album in 1970. Since that time, he has recorded more than 30 albums and scored numerous hits that have gained evergreen status around the world. data.text:
Elton John (born March 25, 1947) is an English vocalist, pianist, songwriter, and philanthropist with a career stretching back to the mid-1960s. He achieved global stardom with his self-titled second album in 1970. Since that time, he has recorded more than 30 albums and scored numerous hits that have gained evergreen status around the world.

Early Life

John was born Reginald Kenneth Dwight on March 25, 1947, in Pinner, Middlesex, England. His father, a Royal Air Force flight lieutenant, was a trumpeter in the Bob Millar Band, which played military dances. The Dwight‚Äôs were avid record buyers, raising Reginald on the popular music of the day. He knew he wanted to be a musician after hearing the early rock n‚Äô roll hits of Little Richard and Jerry Lee Lewis.

Dwight took up piano as a small child, leaning to play pieces like Waldteufel‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Skater‚Äôs Waltz‚Äù by ear. He started taking formal piano lessons at age seven. By age 11, he won a junior scholarship to the Royal Academy of Music. According to one professor, Dwight recited the entirety of a lengthy Handel piece after hearing it once.[1] He attended the academy for five years, singing in the Saturday choir and mastering the works of Fr√©d√©ric Chopin and Johann Sebastian Bach.

The Dwight‚Äôs divorced when Reginald was 14. He moved with his mother and her new husband into a flat on Frome Court, where he remained until he hit paydirt in the states. Around this time, he got a four-nights-weekly pianist residency at the Northwood Hills Hotel. Though normal-sighted, he started wearing horn-rimmed glasses in emulation of Buddy Holly.

Bluesology

In 1962, Dwight formed Bluesology with his neighbor, guitarist Stewart ‚ÄúStu‚Äù Brown. After some months on the local pub circuit, they scored a weekly residency at London‚Äôs Establishment Club with a setlist comprised of blues standards by Muddy Waters, Jimmy Witherspoon, and Memphis Slim.

In 1965, Bluesology signed with an agency that sent them on tour as the UK backing band for visiting American acts, including The Isley Brothers, Doris Troy, Billy Stewart, and Patti LaBelle & the Blue Belles. In July, Bluesology debuted with the Dwight original ‚ÄúCome Back, Baby‚Äù (b/w the Witherspoon cover ‚ÄúTimes Getting Tougher Than Tough‚Äù), followed in November with the Dwight original ‚ÄúMr. Frantic‚Äù (b/w the Slim cover ‚ÄúEveryday (I Have the Blues)‚Äù). Both singles appeared on Fontana; the second features an uncredited early appearance by guitarist Bernie Holland, who later surfaced in Jody Grind, Stealers Wheel, and Hummingbird.

Bluesology expanded to a brass-integrated sextet for a German tour behind American soulster Major Lance. In late 1966, they linked with English blues singer Long John Baldry. Dwight and Brown were the only original members in a lineup that now included (future Soft Machine) saxophonist Elton Dean and (future Juicy Lucy) guitarist Neil Hubbard.

In May 1967, Dwight deputized Simon Dupree & the Big Sound keyboardist Eric Hine on two dates in Scotland. In October, Bluesology signed to Polydor (as Stu Brown & Bluesology) for their third single: ‚ÄúSince I Found You Baby,‚Äù a brassy mid-tempo soul-pop number by veteran English entertainer Kenny Lynch, who co-wrote the b-side (‚ÄúJust a Little Bit‚Äù) with American songwriter Mort Shuman.

In late 1967, Dwight left Bluesology and pursued a songwriting career. He answered an ad in the New Musical Express placed by Liberty records A&R Ray Williams, who introduced Dwight to another respondent, lyricist Bernie Taupin. Dwight and Taupin began a songwriting partnership that would span more than fifty years. Their first completed song was the September 1967 demo ‚ÄúScarecrow.‚Äù Later that year, Dwight adopted the professional name Elton John, derived from his ex-bandmates Elton Dean and Long John Baldry.

1968

In 1968, Elton John and Bernie Taupin became staff writers for Dick James Music (DJM), a publishing company established by English music mogul Dick James (1920‚Äì1986). At DJM, John‚ÄìTaupin wrote songs for assorted pop performers, including Scottish singer Lulu, who recorded their composition ‚ÄúI Can‚Äôt Go On (Living Without You),‚Äù the sixth runner-up to the UK entry in the 1969 Eurovision Song Contest.

As a sessionist, John plays piano on ‚ÄúAn Olympic Record,‚Äù a 1968 Columbia a-side by pop parodists The Barron Knights. He sings backing vocals on one side (‚ÄúLily the Pink‚Äù) by Scaffold, a folk-comedy trio with Mike McGear (aka Peter McCartney, the younger brother of Paul McCartney). Elton plays and sings backup on ‚ÄúDelilah,‚Äù a 1968 global chart-topper by Tom Jones.

Regimental Sgt Zippo

Between November 1967 and May 1968, John recorded his first round of Taupin co-writes at Dick James Studios in London. The intended album ‚Äî shelved in favor of his proper debut Empty Sky ‚Äî appeared fifty-three years after its completion as Regimental Sgt Zippo. It contains twelve psych-tinged originals: ten John‚ÄìTaupin numbers and two (‚ÄúSitting Doing Nothing,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll Be Sorry to See Me Go‚Äù) co-written by DJM session guitarist Caleb Quaye, a late-period Bluesology member who recently cut the Philips psych single ‚ÄúBaby Your Phrasing Is Bad‚Äù (b/w ‚ÄúA Woman of Distinction‚Äù).

‚ÄúWhen I Was Tealby Abbey‚Äù (2:35)

‚ÄúAnd the Clock Goes Round‚Äù (3:06)

‚ÄúSitting Doing Nothing‚Äù (2:30)

‚ÄúTurn to Me‚Äù (3:16)

‚ÄúAngel Tree‚Äù (2:04)

‚ÄúRegimental Sgt. Zippo‚Äù (4:44)

‚ÄúA Dandelion Dies in the Wind‚Äù (3:14)

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll Be Sorry to See Me Go‚Äù (2:34)

‚ÄúNina‚Äù (3:50)

‚ÄúTartan Coloured Lady‚Äù (4:09)

‚ÄúHourglass‚Äù (2:44)

‚ÄúWatching the Planes Go By‚Äù (4:07)

Elton plays organ and piano (grand and electric), plus harpsichord on Regimental Sgt Zippo, which features Quaye on acoustic and electric guitars, flute, percussion, and backing vocals. Two recent members of psychsters The Mirage ‚Äî bassist Dee Murray (a brief Spencer Davis Group player) and drummer Dave Hynes ‚Äî round out Elton‚Äôs studio band.

Quaye produced the songs, which feature select backing by the Paul Fenoulhet Orchestra, conducted by Fenoulhet (1906‚Äì1979) of the WWII-era Skyrockets Dance Orchestra. The engineer, Frank Owen, worked beforehand with the Isle of Wight Cherokees, a precursor to Aubrey Small. Zack Laurence, a veteran Parlophone jazz-pop composer, handles orchestral arrangements.

Regimental Sgt Zippo appeared in 2021 in a vintage psychedelic sleeve that depicts young Elton from multiple angles, engulfed in swirls and enhanced with three colors: mustard, magenta, and turquoise.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve Been Loving You‚Äù

In March 1968, John released his debut solo single, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve Been Loving You,‚Äù a Taupin co-credited number backed with the Elton lone-write ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs to the Next Time.‚Äù Quaye produced the single, which appeared in limited quantity on Philips (UK only). Despite the label info, Elton lone-wrote ‚ÄúI‚Äôve Been Loving You.‚Äù All subsequent originals (through 1976) are genuine John‚ÄìTaupin compositions.

In Portugal, Philips issued ‚ÄúI‚Äôve Been Loving You‚Äù as a maxi-single with one track from the Sgt Zippo sessions (‚ÄúAngel Tree‚Äù) and the 1968 Dick James demo ‚ÄúThank You For All Your Loving.‚Äù

1969

In February 1969, Decca Records issued a single by the Bead and Beer Band titled ‚ÄúDick Barton Theme (The Devil‚Äôs Gallop),‚Äù a cover of the 1946 theme by British composer Charles Williams to the BBC Light Programme serial Dick Barton ‚Äì Special Agent. The Bread and Beer Band was a studio project by Elton, Caleb Quaye, and Hollies bassist Bernie Calvert. They wrote the b-side, ‚ÄúBreakdown Blues,‚Äù with one Lennox Jackson.

John continued as a sessionist with piano credits on 1969 singles by Scaffold (‚ÄúGin Gan Goolie‚Äù) and Family Dogg (‚ÄúA Way of Life‚Äù). He sings backing vocals on both sides of the November CBS release ‚ÄúGood To Be Alive‚Äù (‚ÄúSame Old Story‚Äù), the third single by fifteen-year-old singer Tina Charles, a future UK disco-pop star.

Meanwhile, Simon Dupree & the Big Sound covered the John‚ÄìTaupin number ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Going Home.‚Äù John plays piano on ‚ÄúGive It All Back,‚Äù the b-side of the November 1969 Parlophone single ‚ÄúThe Eagle Flies Tonight,‚Äù the final Big Sound release. Upon their breakup, Big Sound leaders the Shulman brothers considered John as a possible keyboardist‚Äìsinger for their new band, Gentle Giant, but they revoked the invitation after they heard his debut album.

Elton made his second appearance on a global hit with ‚ÄúHe Ain‚Äôt Heavy, He‚Äôs My Brother,‚Äù the September 1969 standalone single by The Hollies. He sings and plays piano on the gospel-tinged ballad, which reached No. 3 in the UK and Irish singles charts and No. 7 on the US Billboard Hot 100. John also plays on the September 1969 DJM single ‚ÄúMr. Boyd‚Äù (b/w ‚ÄúImagine‚Äù) by Argosy, the starting vehicle of musician‚Äìsinger Roger Hodgson, the soon-to-be co-frontman of Supertramp.

‚ÄúLady Samantha‚Äù

In January 1969, John issued his second Philips single, ‚ÄúLady Samantha‚Äù (b/w ‚ÄúAll Across the Havens‚Äù). Both sides were recorded the prior month at DJM Studios and produced by Steve Brown. The songs were performed during Elton‚Äôs first BBC Radio broadcast (10/28/68) but soon dropped from his setlist.

Elton is backed on ‚ÄúLady Samantha‚Äù by Quaye, bassist Tony Murray, and drummer Roger Pope. Murray played concurrently in Plastic Penny, a pop-psych band that made two 1968‚Äì69 albums on Page One. Their second (Currency) contains a cover of the unheard Sgt Zippo number ‚ÄúTurn to Me.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Me That You Need‚Äù

On May 16, 1969, Elton released his third single, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Me That You Need,‚Äù a swelling John‚ÄìTaupin ballad backed with the mid-tempo rustic rocker ‚ÄúJust Like Strange Rain.‚Äù

John recorded both sides with Brown in April at Olympic Studios. He‚Äôs backed on the single by Quaye, Pope, and DJM studio engineer Clive Franks, who plays bass on ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Me That You Need,‚Äù which features strings conducted by Cy Payne, an arranger on recent recordings by The Idle Race, Kate, The Barrier, and select North American acts (Harper and Rowe, The Guess Who).

This was the fifth release on DJM Records (DJS 205), which issued the single in the UK and Italy. Elsewhere, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Me That You Need‚Äù appeared on Fontana (France) and Philips (Singapoe).

In 1971, DJM issued ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Me That You Need‚Äù in Japan, where it reached No. 2 on the Oricon International Singles Chart.

Empty Sky

Elton John released his debut album, Empty Sky, on June 6, 1969, on DJM. It features nine John‚ÄìTaupin originals, including ‚ÄúHymn 2000,‚Äù ‚ÄúWestern Ford Gateway,‚Äù ‚ÄúSkyline Pigeon,‚Äù and ‚ÄúVal-Hala.‚Äù The album opens with the titular ‚ÄúEmpty Sky,‚Äù his second-longest studio original. Empty Sky closes with the lengthy three-part medley ‚ÄúGulliver ‚Äì Hay Chewed ‚Äì Reprise.‚Äù

1. ‚ÄúEmpty Sky‚Äù (8:29)

2. ‚ÄúVal-Hala‚Äù (4:11)

3. ‚ÄúWestern Ford Gateway‚Äù (3:15)

4. ‚ÄúHymn 2000‚Äù (4:29)

1. ‚ÄúLady What‚Äôs Tomorrow‚Äù (3:09)

2. ‚ÄúSails‚Äù (3:45)

3. ‚ÄúThe Scaffold‚Äù (3:18)

4. ‚ÄúSkyline Pigeon‚Äù (3:37)

5. ‚ÄúGulliver ‚Äì Hay Chewed ‚Äì Reprise‚Äù (6:58)

Sessions took place between November 1968 and April 1969 at Dick James Studios. Elton plays Hohner Pianet and harpsichord in addition to piano and organ on Empty Sky, which features Quaye, Pope, and Murray. Quaye and Pope recently formed the band Hookfoot with fellow DJM sessionists but their first-recorded album (A Piece of Pye) wound up shelved for four decades.

One track (‚ÄúLady What‚Äôs Tomorrow‚Äù) features Murray‚Äôs Plastic Penny bandmate, drummer Nigel Olsson. Select passages feature saxophonist Don Fay, a recent backer of bluesman Errol Dixon. Harpist Graham Vickery of Pye blues-rockers Shakey Vick also appears on the album.

DJM music coordinator Steve Brown produced Empty Sky, which Frank Owen engineered in sequence with As I Am, the singular solo album by Troggs guitarist Chris Britton. Clive Franks, the tape operator on Empty Sky, is credited with ‚Äúwhistling.‚Äù

Empty Sky is housed in a gatefold designed by Dave Larkham. The front depicts a line-enhanced blue-scale Elton against a cloudy backdrop. The inner-gates have light blue-scale images of him and Bernie behind a wall of lyrics. The back has white text on purple with credits and liner notes by Tony Brandon and David Symonds (both pictured). Symonds writes that Elton ‚Äúdoes not confine himself to the brighter side of life. The runcible has since changed to the smouldering crucible of a million injustices.‚Äù (Runcible is a nonsense word invented by English Victorian author Edward Lear as a whimsical adjective for objects.)

Empty Sky first appeared in the UK and South Africa. DJM later issued the album in Japan (1970), Oceania and Italy (1972), and Germany and Mexico (1975). In the US, Empty Sky remained unavailable until January 1975 when MCA released to capitalize on Elton‚Äôs transatlantic stardom.

1970

Elton John formed his first backing band with Olsson and Dee Murray. He performed his first show as Elton John on March 25, 1970, at the Revolution Club, a rock hotspot in Bruton Place, Mayfair, in central London. On April 7, he played the Roundhouse, a converted railway shed in Chalk Farm that ushered London‚Äôs psychedelic boom.

As a sessionist, Elton backed Tom Jones on the singer‚Äôs 1970 cover of ‚ÄúI Who Have Nothing,‚Äù a 1963 Leiber‚ÄìStoller song first recorded by Ben E. King. He also plays on the 1970 DJM single ‚ÄúHave You Seen Your Savior‚Äù (b/w ‚ÄúWhite Line Road‚Äù) by Scottish posters My Dear Watson. He appears on one track (‚ÄúJust a Day‚Äù) on the 1970 Vertigo release From Home to Home by Fairfield Parlour, a folk-psyh mutation of Kaleidoscope. Elton also earned two 1970 credits behind The Hollies: their March 1970 a-side ‚ÄúI Can‚Äôt Tell the Bottom From the Top‚Äù and one track (‚ÄúPerfect Lady Housewife‚Äù) on their November Parlophone release Confessions of the Mind (issued stateside as Moving Finger).

Elton sings ‚ÄúFrom Denver to L.A,‚Äù a co-write between Hal Shaper and French film composer Francis Lai for the 1970 British sports drama The Games starring Michael Crawford and Ryan O‚ÄôNeal. American small-press Viking issued the song as a mono / stereo promo single with the singer credited as ‚ÄòElton Johns.‚Äô

Island Records initially booked Elton as a vocalist on the winter‚Äìspring 1970 sessions for In the Wake of Poseidon, the second album by King Crimson. However, KC bandleader Robert Fripp nixed the proposal.

Elton John

Elton John released his self-titled second album on April 10, 1970, on DJM (UK) and Uni (US). It features ten John‚ÄìTaupin originals, including ‚ÄúThe King Must Die,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Greatest Discovery,‚Äù ‚ÄúFirst Episode at Hienton,‚Äù ‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot,‚Äù the much-covered ‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù and the singer‚Äôs international breakthrough hit ‚ÄúYour Song.‚Äù

1. ‚ÄúYour Song‚Äù (4:04)

2. ‚ÄúI Need You to Turn To‚Äù (2:32)

3. ‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot‚Äù (3:46)

4. ‚ÄúNo Shoe Strings on Louise‚Äù (3:31)

5. ‚ÄúFirst Episode at Hienton‚Äù (4:48)

6. ‚ÄúSixty Years On‚Äù (4:35)

7. ‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù (3:22)

8. ‚ÄúThe Greatest Discovery‚Äù (4:12)

9. ‚ÄúThe Cage‚Äù (3:28)

10. ‚ÄúThe King Must Die‚Äù (5:21)

Elton John is the singer‚Äôs first of fourteen albums produced by Gus Dudgeon. Trident staffer Robin Geoffrey Cable engineered this and Elton‚Äôs subsequent three albums. This also marks Elton‚Äôs first of nine pairings with string conductor Paul Buckmaster, who recently arranged singles by Locomotive and David Bowie (‚ÄúSpace Oddity‚Äù). Buckmaster himself performs the cello solo on ‚ÄúThe Greatest Discovery.‚Äù Steve Brown reappears as ‚Äòproduction coordinator.‚Äô

Elton plays harpsichord on ‚ÄúI Need You to Turn To‚Äù and piano throughout the album, which also features organist Brian Dee (‚ÄúSixty Years On,‚Äù ‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù) and Moog synthesizer by Buckmaster‚Äôs wife Diana Lewis (‚ÄúFirst Episode at Hienton,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Cage‚Äù).

Four songs (‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot,‚Äù ‚ÄúNo Shoe Strings on Louise,‚Äù ‚ÄúBorder Song,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Cage‚Äù) feature a six-piece studio choir with members of Blue Mink (Madeline Bell, Roger Cook), Edison Lighthouse (Tony Burrows), The Ladybirds (Kay Garner), and singer‚Äìsongwriters Lesley Duncan and Tony Hazzard.

Elton John features five guitarists: mainly Clive Hicks (six tracks) and Quaye (four), plus Colin Green (Spanish guitar on ‚ÄúSixty Years On‚Äù), Roland Harker (‚ÄúI Need You to Turn To‚Äù), and Rumplestiltskin member Alan Parker (‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot‚Äù). Clark, Green, and Hicks all play on ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Song.‚Äù Colin, Kay, and Belle would all partake in the 1972 Rediffusion project The Seven Ages of Man.

The album has three bassists: Dave Richmond (‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Song,‚Äù ‚ÄúBorder Song,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Greatest Discovery‚Äù), Alan Weighall (‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot,‚Äù ‚ÄúNo Shoe Strings on Louise,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Cage‚Äù), and Les Hurdle (‚ÄúThe King Must Die‚Äù). Richmond, a founding member of Manfred Mann, also plays on 1969‚Äì70 albums by Scott Walker and Bread Love and Dreams (Strange Tale of Captain Shannon and the Hunchback from Gigha).

Blue Mink‚Äôs Barry Morgan drums on five tracks; Pentangle‚Äòs Terry Cox drums on ‚ÄúThe Greatest Discovery‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe King Must Die.‚Äù Harpist Skaila Kanga, a sessionist on James Taylor‚Äôs first album, plays on ‚ÄúI Need You to Turn To‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Greatest Discovery.‚Äù

Original UK copies of Elton John are housed in a matte, textured gatefold sleeve designed by Larkham with photography by Stowell Stanford. It shows Elton‚Äôs shaded, half-visible profile (front), a lyric spread with titles in pink Blackletter font (inner-gates), and a side-to-side photo of the core creative team (Lewis, Buckmaster, John, Taupin, Dudgeon, Quaye, Brown).

DJM lifted ‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù as an advance single on March 20, 1970, backed with the non-album ‚ÄúBad Side of the Moon.‚Äù Elton mimed ‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù on the April 2 broadcast of the BBC music program Top of the Pops, which aired it amid current hits by Juicy Lucy (‚ÄúWho Do You Love?‚Äù), Slade (‚ÄúShape of Things‚Äù), Tom & Dusty Springfield (‚ÄúMorning Please Don‚Äôt Come‚Äù), and Rufus Thomas (‚ÄúDo the Funky Chicken‚Äù).

‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù first appeared in the US on the Congress label and reappeared in July on Uni. It cracked the Billboard Hot 100 at 92. In Canada, the song reached No. 35. Aretha Franklin covered the song as an October 1970 Atlantic a-side (parenthetically subtitled ‚ÄúHoly Moses‚Äù). Her version reached No. 23 on the Cashbox Top 100 and reappeared on her 1972 album Young, Gifted and Black. The 5th Dimension cover ‚ÄúBorder Song‚Äù on their 1972 album Individually & Collectively. Solomon Burke combines ‚ÄúYour Song,‚Äù ‚ÄúBorder Song,‚Äù and ‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot‚Äù in a short medley (3:17) titled ‚ÄúThree Psalms of Elton‚Äù on his 1971 MGM release Electronic Magnetism.

Toe Fat cover ‚ÄúBad Side of the Moon‚Äù on their 1970 second album Toe Fat Two. Canadian rockers April Wine cover the song on their 1972 second album On Record.

Elton promoted the album with an April 21 appearance at Pop Proms 1970, a week-long concert series hosted by Radio One DJ John Peel with sets by Bronco, Fleetwood Mac, Fotheringay, Ginger Baker‚Äôs Air Force, If, Jody Grind, Mighty Baby, Mott the Hoople, Quintessence, and Traffic. John played on Day 2 (Tuesday) along with T. Rex and The Pretty Things. He played four documented May UK shows and had the June 5 headline slot at London‚Äôs Marquee Club.

Elton John peaked at No. 5 on the UK Albums Chart. It also reached No. 4 in Canada and No. 2 in Australia and Denmark.

‚ÄúRock and Roll Madonna‚Äù

On June 19, Elton John released the non-album single ‚ÄúRock and Roll Madonna,‚Äù a 12-bar guitar‚Äìpiano boogie. Quaye, Pope, and Hookfoot bassist Dave Glover play on the track. The b-side, ‚ÄúGrey Seal,‚Äù is a mid-tempo ballad with sparse piano‚Äìvocal verses and a swelling, orchestrated chorus.

‚ÄúRock and Roll Madonna‚Äù remained a non-album track outside of Germany, where Hansa placed it as the opening track on Elton John in lieu of ‚ÄúI Need You to Turn To.‚Äù

In 1973, Elton rerecorded ‚ÄúGrey Seal‚Äù for his seventh album. This version appears on his 1974 UK rarities comp Lady Samantha.

On June 19, 1970, Elton played his first show abroad at Mantorp‚Äôs Racing Circuit in √ñsterg√∂tland, Sweden. On Sunday the 21st, he held his second Roundhouse engagement, followed by a June 26 show at St. Mary‚Äôs College in Twickenham. On July 11, he played Knokke Casino in Knokke, Belgium.

On August 14, Elton played an extended set at the Yorkshire Folk Blues and Jazz Festival, a shambolic three-day hillside event in Krumlin, Barkisland, with sets by Fairport Convention, Groundhogs, Ralph McTell, and Fotheringay. Elton played Day 1 (Friday), which also featured Amazing Blondel, Atomic Rooster, The Humblebums, Manfred Mann Chapter Three, and headliners The Pretty Things. (The intended Saturday headliner, Pink Floyd, didn‚Äôt appear due to bad weather, which forced the festival‚Äôs organizers to cancel Sunday‚Äôs shows.)

First US Show

On August 25, 1970, Elton John made his US debut at the Troubadour on Santa Monica Boulevard in Hollywood, where he held a six-night engagement, supported by singer‚Äìsongwriter David Ackles.

On the first night, Elton floored the audience with an energized set that included numbers from his self-titled album and a cover of the Rolling Stones recent rocker ‚ÄúHonky Tonk Women.‚Äù He performed in a piano power-trio setting with the Olsson‚ÄìMurray rhythm section; no guitarist. They ended the set with a twenty-minute version of the yet-unreleased John‚ÄìTaupin original ‚ÄúBurn Down the Mission.‚Äù

Rock photojournalist Ed Caraeff ‚Äî who caught the famed guitar-burning image of Jimi Hendrix at the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival ‚Äî captured Elton‚Äôs flying stage routine. Between shows, Elton visited the Disneyland Resort in nearby Anaheim and returned with Mickey Mouse ears that he wore on stage at subsequent shows. His newfound flamboyance stunned Olsson and Murray, who knew Elton as the subdued singer‚Äìsongwriter at Dick James Studios. Audiences, likewise, were shocked by the raw energy of his performances and the contrast between his stripped live arrangements and orchestrated studio recordings.

After the Aug. 25‚Äì30 LA engagement, Elton played six straight nights (Sept. 1‚Äì6) at the Troubadour North in San Francisco. On September 10, he made his first appearance in New York City at the Playboy Club. On Sept. 11‚Äì12, he played the Electric Factory in Philadelphia.

Elton, now the conquering hero, played an October 2 homecoming show at London‚Äôs Royal Albert Hall, supported by Sandy Denny and her band Fotheringay.

‚ÄúYour Song‚Äù

On October 26, 1970, Uni Records issued ‚ÄúTake Me to the Pilot‚Äù as Elton John‚Äôs third proper US single. However, DJs favored the b-side, ‚ÄúYour Song,‚Äù which caught on with listeners and prompted Uni to flip sides. With its earnest delivery, universal message, gripping bridge (‚ÄúI hope you don‚Äôt mind, I hope you don‚Äôt mind, that I put down in words‚Äù), and heartfelt refrain (‚Äúhow wonderful life is when you‚Äôre in the world‚Äù), ‚ÄúYour Song‚Äù became his stateside breakthrough hit. It reached No. 8 on the Billboard Hot 100 and Cashbox Top 100 and No. 9 on the US Adult Contemporary chart. The song‚Äôs success lifted its seven-month-old parent album, Elton John, to No. 4 on the Billboard 200.

In Canada, ‚ÄúYour Song‚Äù reached No. 3 on the RPM Top Singles chart and No. 4 on the Adult Contemporary chart.

Tumbleweed Connection

Elton John released his third album, Tumbleweed Connection, on October 30, 1970, on DJM and Uni. It contains nine John‚ÄìTaupin originals and ‚ÄúLove Song,‚Äù which Elton co-wrote with Lesley Duncan. Each side closes with a lengthy epic number: ‚ÄúMy Father‚Äôs Gun‚Äù and ‚ÄúBurn Down the Mission.‚Äù Musically and lyrically, the songs invoke Old West themes.

1. ‚ÄúBallad of a Well-Known Gun‚Äù (4:59)

2. ‚ÄúCome Down in Time‚Äù (3:25)

3. ‚ÄúCountry Comfort‚Äù (5:06) Rod Stewart covers this song on his June 1970 second album Gasoline Alley, released four months ahead of Tumbleweed.

4. ‚ÄúSon of Your Father‚Äù (3:48) Spooky Tooth cover this song on their July 1970 fourth album The Last Puff, released three months before Tumbleweed.

5. ‚ÄúMy Father‚Äôs Gun‚Äù (6:20)

6. ‚ÄúWhere to Now St. Peter?‚Äù (4:11)

7. ‚ÄúLove Song‚Äù (3:41)

8. ‚ÄúAmoreena‚Äù (5:00)

9. ‚ÄúTalking Old Soldiers‚Äù (4:06)

10. ‚ÄúBurn Down the Mission‚Äù (6:21)

bonus 11. ‚ÄúInto the Old Man‚Äôs Shoes‚Äù

Sessions took place in March 1970 at Trident, where Dudgeon produced the album in sequence with titles by Magna Carta and Michael Chapman. This is Elton‚Äôs second album engineered by Geoffrey Cable, who worked on concurrent titles by Affinity (self-titled), Andwella, Genesis (Trespass), Harvey Andrews, Jade, and Van der Graaf Generator (The Least We Can Do, H to He).

The Rocket Record Company

In 1973, Elton John founded the Rocket Record Company in partnership with Bernie Taupin, Gus Dudgeon, and Steve Brown. Elton talks about the venture in the August 16 issue of Rolling Stone (No. 141), which depicts the singer in a cartoon cover illustration by Kim Whitesides. In the six-page feature by writer and radio presenter Paul Gambaccini, Elton insists that he co-founded the label to nurture up-and-coming talent; not to promote his own releases (he points to the Moody Blues and their Threshold label as an example of a small roster drowned by its star act).

Hentschel, who plays ARP on ‚ÄúJanine,‚Äù co-engineered the Dudgeon-produced album with Ken Scott.

In January 1974, Elton John recorded new music at the recently opened Caribou Ranch, a converted barn facility in the Rocky Mountains near Nederland, Colorado.
